bio: Daniel Huang is a banking reporter out of the New York bureau of The Wall Street Journal.

stories.title: Dividends Boost Tech-Stock Allure
stories.dek: Technology stocks that predate the internet bubble are hot again, thanks to a feature that many tech firms consciously eschewed in those days: hefty dividends.

stories.title: In Rush to Serve More Veterans, VA Opens Door to Disability Fraud
stories.dek: Disability benefits have soared as the embattled Veterans Affairs department expands coverage and streamlines the claims process. Now, some critics say the reduced evidence requirements can mean claims get padded.

stories.title: Tech Stocks Rebound in May After Rough Start to Year
The Bank of China Takes Manhattan
stories.dek: One of China’s biggest lenders is planting its flag in the middle of Manhattan, a symbolic move for a bank with ambitions to challenge Wall Street on its home turf.

stories.title: Millennial Employees Confound Big Banks
Wall Street’s Playbook for Managing Millennials
stories.dek: Efforts by Wall Street firms to retain young talent range from protected days off and less grunt work to speeding the path to promotions.

stories.title: As Valeant Goes, So Goes Sequoia
stories.dek: A look at the figures highlights just how much Sequoia Fund's performance has depended on Valeant.

stories.title: VA Disciplines Some Staff Over Alleged Discriminatory Remarks
stories.dek: The Department of Veterans Affairs disciplined two judges and proposed action against three staff attorneys after an internal investigation revealed email exchanges that allegedly carried discriminatory remarks.

stories.title: J.P. Morgan to Workaholics: Knock It Off
stories.dek: J.P. Morgan Chase launched a new effort to encourage its investment bankers to take their weekends off—as long as there isn’t a live deal in the works.

stories.title: Why an Old Scam Keeps Landing in Your Inbox
stories.dek: Pump-and-dump stock schemes, chronicled in ‘The Wolf of Wall Street,’ are getting new life from successive generations of technology, as the J.P. Morgan hacking case illustrates.

stories.title: Fake Hedge-Fund Manager Convicted of Securities Fraud
stories.dek: A Manhattan man was convicted of a brazen financial scam in which he claimed to be running a hedge fund with eye-popping returns when in fact he was a former waiter who spent his investors’ money on steak dinners, jewelry and airline tickets.

stories.title: Fintech Startups Join Forces With Former Foe: Banks
stories.dek: After years of staking combative positions, financial technology—or “fintech”—upstarts are rethinking relationships with the big banks.

stories.title: Bank of America Cut Off Finance Sites From Its Data
stories.dek: The temporary move highlights unease roiling banks amid threat from tech-savvy startups trying to lure away business.

stories.title: E*Trade Swings to Loss
stories.dek: E*Trade Financial reported a third-quarter loss Thursday after recording charges during the period related to the termination of its wholesale funding obligations.

stories.title: Citigroup in Talks to Sell Its 20% Stake in China Guangfa Bank
stories.dek: Citigroup is in talks to sell its minority stake in China Guangfa Bank, a holding the New York firm acquired in 2006 as part of a fierce takeover battle, according to people familiar with the matter.

stories.title: Did Cronkite’s Gift Really Come From Hitler’s Urinal?
stories.dek: Famed newsman Walter Cronkite once gave a friend an unusual birthday present: a shard of porcelain he said came from Hitler’s lavatory.

stories.title: Scottrade Discloses Data Breach Potentially Targeting 4.6 Million Clients
stories.dek: Discount brokerage Scottrade Inc. disclosed a data breach Friday that appeared to target the names and street addresses of about 4.6 million clients.

stories.title: Turmoil Brings a Rush to Trade
stories.dek: Financial advisers told the jittery on Monday that the stock-market rout isn’t a repeat of the financial crisis, but many rushed to sell anyway.

stories.title: Online Brokerage Firms Overwhelmed by Selloff
stories.dek: TD Ameritrade and Scottrade report increases in trading volume and issues in executing trades.

stories.title: SEC Says Felon Defied Ban on Accounting Work
stories.dek: The SEC says Stephen P. Corso, an accountant convicted of wire fraud, resurfaced from a short jail stint by changing his name slightly to prepare financial statements for companies, even though he was forbidden to do so.
